item.title: How we’re strengthening our fight against online scams in APAC with a $5M fund from Google.org

review.headline_rewrite: How we’re strengthening our fight against online scams in APAC with a $5M fund from Google.org
bullets:
How we’re strengthening our fight against online scams in APAC with a $5M fund from Google.org
Scams and fraud continue to impact millions across Southeast Asia, accounting for an estimated $23.6 billion across the region in 2024.

At the GASA Anti-Scam Summit 2025 in Singapore, we announced $5 million in funding from Google.org to The ASEAN Foundation to expand online scam prevention resources to 3 million people in Southeast Asia.

This includes scaling “Be Scam Ready” (formerly known as ShieldUp!), an educational game that helps build resilience against online threats by exposing players to common scam tactics in a safe environment.
Tracking over 400 million threat signals in real-time, member organizations can rapidly share information to disrupt fraud.

item.title: OpenAI acquires product testing startup Statsig and shakes up its leadership team

review.headline_rewrite: OpenAI acquires product testing startup Statsig and shakes up its leadership team
bullets: OpenAI announced in a blog post on Tuesday that it agreed to acquire the product testing startup, Statsig, and bring on its founder and CEO, Vijaye Raji, as the company’s CTO of Applications.

OpenAI is paying $1.1 billion for Statsig in an all-stock deal — one of the largest acquisitions ever for the ChatGPT maker — under the company’s current $300 billion valuation, OpenAI spokesperson Kayla Wood told TechCrunch.
The acquisition marks OpenAI’s latest effort to build out its Applications business, helmed by the former CEO of Instacart, Fidji Simo, who started work at the company a few weeks ago.
Raji will report to Simo and will head product engineering for ChatGPT, the company’s AI coding tool Codex, and future applications that OpenAI plans to build.
The company says that bringing Statsig’s experimentation platform in-house will accelerate product development across the Applications organization.
As Raji comes on board, OpenAI is making changes to its leadership team.

item.title: Astro Teller, ‘Captain of Moonshots,’ joins TechCrunch Disrupt 2025 this October

review.headline_rewrite: Astro Teller, ‘Captain of Moonshots,’ joins TechCrunch Disrupt 2025 this October
bullets: Teller believes failure should be celebrated quickly because it clears the runway for the breakthroughs that change everything.

Why you should be at Disrupt 2025
As AI blurs the line between science fiction and reality, Teller’s insights on how to think bigger, fail smarter, and build for impact couldn’t be more timely.
Don’t wait — the next price jump is around the corner.

item.title: Here are the best AirPods deals you can get right now

review.headline_rewrite: Here are the best AirPods deals you can get right now
bullets: If you know where to look, you can often score discounts on Apple’s ever-expanding AirPods lineup.
Both the newer AirPods Max and AirPods 4 (with and without ANC) now consistently receive discounts, as do the latest AirPods Pro with USB-C.

Here are the best AirPods deals you can get right now
There are deals available on every model, from the latest entry-level AirPods 4 to the noise-canceling AirPods Pro.
Below, we’ve rounded up the best deals currently available on each model, including both iterations of the AirPods 4, the latest AirPods Pro, and the AirPods Max.

Just keep in mind that Apple’s next big event is scheduled for September 9th, meaning it’s possible that we’ll see a new pair of AirPods Pro before October rolls around, possibly with heart rate monitoring and a slew of AI-based features.

The best AirPods 4 deals
At its September 2024 event, Apple introduced the AirPods 4, a pair of wireless earbuds available in two variations: a $129 standard model and a $179 noise-canceling model.

item.title: OpenAI shuffles executive roles, acquires Statsig for $1.1 billion

review.headline_rewrite: OpenAI shuffles executive roles, acquires Statsig for $1.1 billion
bullets: OpenAI has started to build out its Applications team under Fidji Simo, its new CEO of Applications, who left her former position as Instacart’s CEO to start in the executive role on August 18th.
On Tuesday, the company confirmed it’s shuffling executive roles, bringing on a new CTO of applications, and acquiring a product analytics company for $1.1 billion.

Statsig, the company OpenAI is acquiring, specializes in A/B testing and other features for companies looking to improve their products, and OpenAI is bringing on its founder and CEO, Vijaye Raji, as a new C-suite executive.

Raji will be OpenAI’s CTO of Applications, heading up product engineering for both ChatGPT and Codex, “with responsibilities that span core systems and product lines including infrastructure and Integrity,” OpenAI wrote in a blog post.
“Once the acquisition is finalized, Statsig employees will become OpenAI employees,” OpenAI wrote in the blog post, noting that the deal’s close will be subject to regulatory approval.

We’ll take a measured approach to any future integration, ensuring continuity for current customers and enabling the team to stay focused on what they do best.”
OpenAI also announced it was shuffling some other executive positions.

item.title: Google says Gmail security is “strong and effective” as it denies major breach

review.headline_rewrite: Google says Gmail security is “strong and effective” as it denies major breach
bullets: The sky is falling, and Gmail has supposedly been hacked to bits by malicious parties unknown.
Reports circulated last week claiming that Gmail was the subject of a major data breach, citing a series of warnings Google has distributed and increasing reports of phishing attacks.
In a brief post on its official blog, Google says that Gmail's security is "strong and effective," and reports to the contrary are mistaken.
This story seems to have developed due to a random confluence of security events.
Google experienced a Gmail data breach in June, but the attack was limited to the company's corporate Salesforce server.
The hacker was able to access publicly available information like business names and contact details, but no private information was compromised.
